results.title: Pacific terminal
results.creator_credit: Government of NSW and Commonwealth Department of Information
results.brief_description: A survey of the capital city of New South Wales, Sydney on Port Jackson. Includes aerial footage of Sydney; monuments in Macquarie Place; inland footage of shearers and bullocks hauling logs; and Australians enjoying a range of recreational activities.

results.title: Pacific Rim
results.headline_credit: Canada and United States of America, 2013
results.brief_description: When legions of monstrous creatures, known as Kaiju, started rising from the sea, a war began that would take millions of lives and consume humanity’s resources for years on end. To combat the giant Kaiju, a special type of weapon was devised: massive robots, called Jaegers, which are controlled simultaneously by two pilots whose minds are locked in a neural bridge. But even the Jaegers are proving nearly defenseless in the face of the relentless Kaiju. On the verge of defeat, the forces defending mankind have no choice but to turn to two unlikely heroes—a washed-up former pilot (Charlie Hunnam) and an untested trainee (Rinko Kikuchi)—who are teamed to drive a legendary but seemingly obsolete Jaeger from the past. Together, they stand as mankind’s last hope against the mounting apocalypse.

results.title: Pacific paradise?
results.creator_credit: Oliver Howes, Paul Humfress and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Human face of the Pacific”.
The three parts of this program show Pacific island nations, which have been affected to a greater or lesser degree by European colonisation. “Part 1. Kiribati” Formerly known as the Gilbert Islands, Kiribati is now independent from the British and still maintains a largely traditional way of life, expressed in its vibrant music and culture. “Part 2. Tahiti” The town of Papeete is a cosmopolitan mix of French and Polynesian, and attracts many island people to its city way of life. “Part 3. The Marshall Islands” Because of the U.S. use of Bikini Atoll for nuclear bomb testing, the inhabitants have been displaced to one small island, dependent for their welfare on the U.S. Unable to return to their homes for many decades, their culture is being lost in third world slum life. A teacher’s guide accompanies this video.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Oliver Howes, Paul Humfress and Film Australia

results.title: Pacific Island life: village life
results.creator_credit: Hermann Schlenker and International Film Foundation
results.brief_description:
Part of a series of five films which examine aspects of life in the Pacific Islands. Shows daily life in the village, including the building of a home.
Suitable for middle and upper primary level.

results.title: Pacific Island life: food from the sea
results.creator_credit: Hermann Schlenker and International Film Foundation
results.brief_description: Examines aspects of life in the Pacific Islands. Shows the lagoon being searched for clams, sea-worms, crabs and turtles. A coconut crab is caught and cooked in an open fire and the shell is used as a container, tool or toy. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: Pacific Island life: fishing
results.creator_credit: Hermann Schlenker and International Film Foundation
results.brief_description: Examines aspects of life in the Pacific Islands. Shows the men preparing for the catch by trapping small fish in the lagoon which they then take beyond the coral reef at the mouth of the channel and use as bait to attract the larger bait. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: Pacific Island life: family life
results.creator_credit: Hermann Schlenker and International Film Foundation
results.brief_description: Examines aspects of life in the Pacific Islands. Each family has its own field usually on one of the more fertile islands. Teheilau and his family take a boat trip to attend to their plot where they grow taro and tumeric. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: Pacific hitchhike
results.creator_credit: Peter Hennessy, Films of Fact and Central Office of Information
results.brief_description: A World War II correspondant travels by a R.N. destroyer to join an aircraft carrier near the Admiralty Islands in the Pacific. Shows the transferring between moving ships, of men, mail and stores. Includes scenes of a 100 mph tornado, and shots of planes hiking and landing back onto the deck of the carrier. Photographs by Peter Hennessy.

results.title: Pacific Canada
results.brief_description: A study of Vancouver, British Columbia, and the Yukon, showing the influence which climate and both ocean and trans-continental transportation has on the fishing, lumbering, mining and smelting and agricultural industries of these provinces.

results.title: Pacific 231
results.brief_description: A visual interpretation of Arthur Honneger’s symphonic poem ‘Pacific 231’ originally written to accompany a silent film. The music was inspired by the thunderous power of a locomotive roaring through the quiet French countryside. The action of the film begins in a roadhouse in Paris as the engine is being prepared for its run. The natural sounds in the train yard gradually merge into Honneger’s music which then provides the only commentary to the visuals. Throughout the film, shots of the locomotive, tracks, fleeting scenery and the patterns of moving pistons and wheels create abstract designs synchronised with the music. (Award: Prize for editing at the 1949 Cannes Film Festival)
